lexUnit.name: grill.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: subject to intense questioning or interrogation.

sentence.text: Service wives did not grill their husbands about bloody work .
None of them really grilled Mr Major about Maastricht .
` I thought you came round here to ask if I 'd seen anything suspicious last night , not grill me about my sex life . "
In his quiet way he really grilled me about Sandy . "
My father grilled us about what we had been doing all week .
She grilled him about women she saw in hotel lobbies , as if he knew each one personally .
But as they started to grill him on such matters as his attitude to South Africa and Northern Ireland , it was his actions , not his befuddled replies , which riveted the panel 's attention .
The appointment was Mr Bush 's finest domestic achievement : listening to Justice Souter grill a lawyer before the court is now one of the great treats of Washington .
As anti-pylons campaigners grilled the National Grid during the second week of the Northallerton hearing , an expert witness agreed that burying cables would eliminate the field .
He took to it like a duck to water and from then on he 'd grill me for hours on end about the various types of plays , especially when we were watching it on TV .
The priest whom she eventually accosted took one look at her , an ill-proportioned , arrogant child with cheap clips in her gaudy hair , and started grilling her for an address .
` Not too good , I 've heard , " said Greg , not adding that he had just been grilling the doctor who signed her second husband 's death certificate .
Extraordinary that the Soviets had not already grilled and broken this man , unbelievable that they had permitted a trial for espionage to go ahead without the evidence of a confession .
She was n't looking forward to being grilled about her friend Caroline .

He looked dismayed , as if the word conjured up a vision of a formal enquiry , with everyone being grilled about their movements and the happy atmosphere of his beloved school fouled by dark suspicions .
Players were grilled about methods of payments in an exercise lasting over two hours .
ENGLAND vice-captain Alec Stewart will be grilled about ball-tampering at his shamed county Surrey .
Speaking in fluent English , she even raised a laugh in court , as she was grilled by defence barrister Anthony Arlidge , QC .
Furious staff claim they were even called in from holidays to be grilled by a specialist security firm at the MetroCentre in Gateshead , Tyne and Wear .
At 4pm , the RBS Chairman and Director of Personnel were grilled by a Parliamentary committee on the job cuts and the responsibility of training staff for the new demands .
The idea of Wheeler being grilled by the police cheered her enormously .
When Mr Rowland bid for the group in 1981 , he and his colleagues were grilled by the Monopolies and Mergers Commission about their plans for Harrods .
Because he had actually found the cut wires he was grilled for several days , as were several other suspects , all electricians .
I grilled a man called George Evans , the managing director of their operations here on the Continent .
It was a technique he employed when grilling a suspect he knew well .
Connie Fraser tells me Vecchi 's been grilling her .

It was Sir Robin , amiably grilling the leader of the Opposition , who forced Mr Kinnock into the open about his Damascene conversions in favour of the European Community and against unilateral disarmament .
The next rough ride came when the youngsters grilled Lord Kearton , Sir Andrew Huxley and William Shelton , a junior minister at the Department of Education and science .
If they really wanted to find a motive for the murder , they should grill Mrs Sweet .
Says singer Danny Bowles : ` They held us against a wall and grilled us .
And having got our agreement in theory he would begin grilling the poor waiter .
` Even so , the Intelligence arm will want to grill you . "
